pullrequest.title: Reduce the symbol load caused by feature templates

content.raw: Unit tests on the structs are kind of tricky, since they’re only used during compile-time. The fact that everything is compiling indicates that they’re working as intended. But I’ll try to think through some reasonable unit tests \(which will probably all be compilation tests\).
content.html: Unit tests on the structs are kind of tricky, since they’re only used during compile-time. The fact that everything is compiling indicates that they’re working as intended. But I’ll try to think through some reasonable unit tests (which will probably all be compilation tests).

pullrequest.title: Reduce the symbol load caused by feature templates

content.raw:
On the topic of ABI, I don’t think a typical ABI checker is going to catch the full picture here. 

The ABI changes should be totally fine for libraries that are simply using `ignition-physics` internally, but I believe there could easily be ABI issues for any libraries that are passing `ignition-physics` entity types \(e.g. `Link3d<SomeFeautreList>`, `Joint3d<SomeFeatureList>`\) between library boundaries \(i.e. using these object types in their public API\).

I don’t think anyone is doing that currently, so these changes should be okay. But if that’s not the case, then there _could_ be some cause for concern. Then again it’s entirely possible that it still would not be a concern at all, because it’s possible that the compiler is producing an object with the exact same memory footprint despite the massive changes in inheritance hierarchy; I honestly don’t know.
content.html:
On the topic of ABI, I don’t think a typical ABI checker is going to catch the full picture here.

The ABI changes should be totally fine for libraries that are simply using ignition-physics internally, but I believe there could easily be ABI issues for any libraries that are passing ignition-physics entity types (e.g. Link3d<SomeFeautreList>, Joint3d<SomeFeatureList>) between library boundaries (i.e. using these object types in their public API).

I don’t think anyone is doing that currently, so these changes should be okay. But if that’s not the case, then there could be some cause for concern. Then again it’s entirely possible that it still would not be a concern at all, because it’s possible that the compiler is producing an object with the exact same memory footprint despite the massive changes in inheritance hierarchy; I honestly don’t know.

It's always tricky to make this kind of assumption about open source software. But I'd say we can afford the risk at this time. Thanks for the analysis.

pullrequest.title: Reduce the symbol load caused by feature templates

content.raw:
I tried really hard today to push the compile times down even further. The attempt can be found in `reduce_inspect_features_symbols`\` and `reduce_determine_plugin_symbols`. It seems I still have something to learn about exactly what influences compile times because both of those attempts only made the compile times worse :cold_sweat:   
  
It seems that the current state of the compile times is good enough, so I think I’ll stop trying to push it down further now. I can revisit the matter later if we reach something like hundreds of features and the compile times become a problem again.

I think I’ve addressed all the code check complaints. There were actually unit tests already in place to cover most of what was touched by this PR. I added a little more to `FeatureList_TEST` to cover the new templates that were introduced.

Tomorrow is a holiday in Singapore, but if there is anything that needs my attention I’m happy to stab at this some more to get it in before the code freeze.
content.html:
I tried really hard today to push the compile times down even further. The attempt can be found in reduce_inspect_features_symbols` and reduce_determine_plugin_symbols. It seems I still have something to learn about exactly what influences compile times because both of those attempts only made the compile times worse

It seems that the current state of the compile times is good enough, so I think I’ll stop trying to push it down further now. I can revisit the matter later if we reach something like hundreds of features and the compile times become a problem again.

I think I’ve addressed all the code check complaints. There were actually unit tests already in place to cover most of what was touched by this PR. I added a little more to FeatureList_TEST to cover the new templates that were introduced.

Tomorrow is a holiday in Singapore, but if there is anything that needs my attention I’m happy to stab at this some more to get it in before the code freeze.
